subsection_content:
Acute pyelonephritis is an acute bacterial infection, also known as upper urinary tract infection. This is a disease caused by bacterial attack, leading to inflammation around the renal calyces, renal pelvis, ureters and kidney parenchyma. This bacteria can move from the bladder up the ureters to the renal pelvis or enter the bloodstream when the patient has sepsis.
Pyelonephritis often presents suddenly with signs and symptoms of systemic inflammation, which can  cause serious complications and patients often present with severe pain in the lower back area. However, if the disease is detected early, most patients are treated as outpatients with antibiotics, and very few patients need to be hospitalized. (first)
